fol.92v
A memoriall of the proceedeinge w
th
the Deputies of the States
4 Januarij
1594
M
r
Bodeley was sente to the Stat
to declare what losses had happened to
her Ma
tie
, her Crowne and Subject
by
the warres w
ch
she hathe w
th
the
Ke
of Spayne
for aydeinge of them of
the Country, and by the greate conty-
nuall expenses of her treasure, and
wasteinge of her Subject
. In w
ch
respecte her Ma
tie
desired to be
eased of her contynuall burthen
and be reembused of some
te of
her Ma
ties
charges, And alsoe at that
tyme her Ma
tie
remembred unto them
the leavie of 1500 men by
S
r
Francis
Veere
, w
ch
was promised should be
retourned upon the recovery of
Groninge
At this tyme alsoe they were required
to discharge her Ma
tie
of a debte
due to
S
r
Horatio Palavincino
/ w
ch
ought to have bene paid by the
Stat
in 81. For lacke of paym
t
where of her ma
tie
hathe bene charged
w
th
the Yearlie interest for the
w
ch
the States did promise in ther
fol.93r
1596
Assembly at
Delfte
in the Yeare 81
to discharge her ma
tie
w
ch
hathe not bene
formed./
[Ap]
ril 1595
The States answeringe there unto did
declare their encrease of charges, and
namely for their shippeinge maynteyned
in 88. againste the Enemy and their
expences in 89 for the Journey of
Portingale
: and likewise for the aydeinge
of her Ma
tie
w
th
their navye in
Brittayne
w
th
out any
ticuler
answere to her Ma
ties
demaundes
p
r
supposed that this proposition of her
Ma
ties
requeste cannot convenyentlie be
communicated to the provynces w
th
out daunger./
[.]
1595
A secret motion was made to M
r
Bodeley to have the Queene
suaded to be contented w
th
these offers
of the States. Firste to acquite her
Ma
tie
of all the charges of the
auxiliarie forces/ and alsoe of the
Cautionarie when soever her Ma
tie
should
be pleased to delyver the townes./
Secondlie to make a Yearlie payment
xx
M
li
to contynue certeyne yeares
fol.93v
as may be agreed betwixte her ma
tie
and them./
Thirdly to ayde her Ma
tie
w
th
their shipinge
or other meanes uppon her Ma
ties
requisition
Forthlie not to enter into treatie of
peace w
th
the K of Spayne, nor w
th
any
Portingall
Potentate w
th
out
her Ma
tie
allowance/
Fiftely to paye to her Ma
tie
after the
Country shalbe broughte to peaceable
estate, or become united w
th
the reste
of the Provynces the S
o
me of C
M
li
Yearly by the space of 4. 4. of more
Yeares./
Lastelie it was concluded by the partie
that the States mighte be induced to
these offers uppon this onely condic
o
n
that dureinge the tyme of their troubles
they may be
mitted to enterteyne
4000 footemen Englishe and therto
added a requeste to have all reconing
stricken uppe/ and acquitted/
fol.94r
1596
Au
gust
1595
M
r
Bodeley revived her Ma
ties
petic
o
ns, but ther unto he coulde gett
noe resolute answere. and soe the matter
March. 95
was delayed untyll the xxj
th
of
Marche
followeinge, at w
ch
tyme they made
him answere, that they had resolved
to p
r
sent their offers to her Ma
tie
: by
Delegates
and there w
th
a release of the
auxiliarie Charges and xx
M
li
sterlinge
Yearly
inge
till the ende of the Warre
w
ch
they restrayned onely to her Ma
ties
life, and not to her Successors, contrary
to the wordes of the treaty
.85.
Againste
the w
ch
M
r
Bodeley did oppose him
selfe, sheweinge, that he had noe
C
o
mission from her Ma
tie
to allowe of ther
offers./
Martij 95
The States doe delyver to M
r
Bodeley
ther offers in Writeinge: to w
ch
M
r
Bodeley answered, that he had newes
acquaynted her Ma
ties
w
th
ther former
offers, neither that he had Comission
to accepte the same./
Martij
[9]
6
Articles were delyvered in writeinge, contayninge
request
of the Stat
to contynue her
Ma
ties
succors, and if not, that they mighte
duringe the Warre entertayne at their
fol.94v
expences fower, or five thowsand Englishe
souldiers, addeinge that if her Ma
tie
:
woulde be discharged of the auxiliarie
souldiors
Companies, the same coulde
not be done but twoe monthes after
the States shalbe advertised of her
Ma
ties
resolution likewise if her Ma
tie
woulde be discharged of the cautionarie
she mighte soe be in delyv
r
inge of the
townes. But if she shalbe pleased
to keepe them still, the same may be
w
th
out prejudice and w
th
out any
charge, or obligac
o
n of the States for
the same./ But only for the servic
in powder accordinge to the treatie
Furthermore they offer to sende yearly
an honorable legac
o
n at the daye of her
Ma
ties
Natyvitie, w
th
offer also of xx
ti
M
li
yearely dureinge the Warre, the same
to be payde onlye to her Ma
ties
sone
and not otherwise/
It
m
they offer also iiij
xx
M
li
ster
l
to be paid
yearly for 4 yeares after the ende
of the Warre, and then the an
u
ytie
of xx
M
li
to cease/
fol.95r
1596
It
m
they desier that it may please her
Ma
tie
for reneweinge of all ther former offers
to discharge them of all obligations
and interest
, that her Ma
tie
, or any
other hathe by mighte or action or
maye have uppon the
Lowe Countries
in ge
n
all or any members of the
same in
ticular, saveinge that her
Ma
tie
maye have her remedie againste
the other provynces nowe occupied
by the Enemy./
Item it is required that the States
mighte sende their deputies w
th
these offers. To w
ch
M
r
Gilpyn
answered in writeinge that her
Ma
tie
had seene their articles deli
v
ed
to M
r
Bodeley, w
ch
beinge visited
by her Ma
tie
she did apprehend the
representac
o
n, and the reembursem
tt
to be very shorte in proportion to
her longe and greate charges
And that also di
v
se poyntes conteyned
in those articles required a further
considerac
o
n, w
ch
mighte be better
voyded by mutuall conference and
thoughe her Ma
tie
founde it inconve
nyent to assure them before their
fol.95v
C
o
meinge of her satisfaction. Yet
she was contented, that they mighte
come, if they soe thoughte good/
This muche hathe passed
before the c
o
minge of the
Deputies into
Englande
/
29 Sep
t.
1596
The deputies were treated w
th
all
to understande whether they had any
larger authorities to encrease their
offers and to alter the same, w
ch
they
denyed to have. And theruppon it
was declared unto them, that her Ma
tie
coulde not accepte of ther offers
sheweinge many
ticular reasons for
mayntennance there of./
4 Octo
b.
96
The deputies doe
siste in requeste
to have their offers accepted, and
ticularlye, toucheinge certeyne
obligac
o
ns, and namely the debte of
Palavincino
./ they did include the discharge
therof, for that they thoughte they
shoulde be charged there w
th
though
they doe maynteyne it, that they be
not bounde there unto/
A large discourse hath bene mad
e
fol.96r
A large discourse hathe bene made, and
reade in writeinge answeringe all
the partes of ther overtures in orders
amongeste w
ch
, these w
ch
followe are
principallie to be noted/
The offer of xx
M
li
in name of
gratuitie seemeth very late consideringe
her Ma
tie
aydes have contynued these
xix yeares In w
ch
tyme noe
signification of gratuitie hathe bene
offered
It
m
ther offers of iiij
xx
M
li
yearlie for
4 Yeares after the warre have
suche uncerteyntie for any tyme
of paymentt, and likewise it it soe
small a s
o
me to satisfie her Ma
ties
Charges, w
ch
dothe amounte above
xj
C
M
li
ster
l
besides other due debt
of greate value not conteyned in the
contracte, and namely that of
Palavincino
, as in noe wise her Ma
tie
can accepte therof./
It
m
also for those respect
her Ma
tie
thinketh
their requeste unreasonable to be
discharged not onely of all S
o
mes due
by force of the treatie, but also of all
fol.96v
1596.
former
ticular bandes of greate
S
o
mes of mony Lente unto the
States in the Yeares 77.78. & 81
for the w
ch
her Ma
tie
hathe their band
besides a spetiall debte due by them
for her Ma
ties
charges for leavye of
men for the releise of
Antwerpe
w
ch
amounteinge to neere hande
xx
ti
M
li
shoulde have bene paide
w
th
in xij monthes after.
In
In conclusion they were required
to sende to the States to have
some further authoritie to enlarge
their offers/.
14 Octo
b.
96
The Deputies make answere, that they
have not thoughte it good to sende to
the States for any larger authoritie
But yet they have advertised them
x Dayes paste of their conferenc
had w
th
the Counsaill. And where
it was alledged that So
v
eigne Princes
may uppon juste causes de
te from
their treaties, they denye the some
to be agreable to Lawe. they answer
that their offer, of satisfaction hathe
not bene very late, consideringe noe
day of payment is yet to come
fol.97r
1596
daye of paymente is yet come
Item they alledge it, not to be reasonable
at this tyme to reenter into the matter
of Accompt
./
A memoriall how to proceed
presentlie w
th
the deputies
Firste to repeate unto them howe this
matter nowe offered hathe had the
beginninge, and processe, declareinge
at all tymes her Ma
ties
mislikeinge
of the offers and of her determynac
o
n
to be disburdened of her greate
charges in respecte of the newe trobles
groweinge from the mightines of the
K of Spayne and of her p
r
sente
troubles in Ireland. And therfore it
may seeme reasonable to assentte
to these thinges followeinge
Firste to require an encrease of the
xx
ti
M
li
yearlie and the paymentt
therof not to be restrayned to her
Ma
ties
life onelie, whereby if god
shoulde shorten the same (as noe
cristian oughte to forethinke) it shold
prove onely profitable to the states
to be discharged of their greate
fol.97v
debt by the decease of her Ma
tie
a matter very uncomfortable to all
sons w
ch
have intereste in her Ma
ties
liefe. And the paymente of this
Amitie to be accounted in
te of the
debte that shalbe due by vertue of
the contracte
Secondly it is to be allowed to discharge
her Ma
tie
of the auxiliarie companyes
and ther w
th
to agree to their requeste
for the entertayneinge of a convenient
nombre of Englishe, uppon their
charges
It
m
it is juste and reasonable to demand
a discharge of the debte due to
Palavincino
the principall beinge
xxxiij
m
CCC lxxiij
li
iiij
s
iiij
d
and
likewise to reembourse to her Ma
tie
the s
o
me of xlv
m
ij
C
lvij
li
vij
s
ij
d
ob
paid for the intereste of the same
for discharge whereof the States
are bounde to [save] bothe her Ma
tie
for her
te and the Cittie of
London
harmelesse for their bond
delyvered at the requeste of the
States.
fol.98r
It
m
suche other debt
as are due by bondes
maybe be forborne at this p
r
sente untill
the States may be more able to
acquite the same/
It
m
soe maye alsoe the reemboursement
of her Ma
ties
greate charges be at
some more convenyent tyme accompted
uppon w
th
allowances to the States
of all lawfull exceptions./ And the
same beinge determyned may be
forborne to be demaunded untill mor
convenyent tyme. In w
ch
poynte it
is to be considered that a certeyne
acte made by the States 2 Octo
b
85
whereby is comprehended the reduction
of the debte due for the releife of
Andwerp
shoulde be reduced to be
payable in the ende of the warre:
the same acte was never allowed by
her Ma
tie
but onely accepted by
M
r
Davison
by waye of a viewe, & ap
bation
whereunto neither her Ma
tie
nor anye
her Comissioners did ever assente, soe
as the same debte for Antwe
r
pe remayneth
due accordeinge to the provitionall
treatye for the releife of Antwerpe
